Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story: I sit at my desk, headset snug against my ear, the hum of the call center a constant backdrop. As a telemarketer, I’m expected to handle every objection with a smile, to keep my voice calm and persuasive, even when the questions are repetitive and the script is all I have to lean on. Today, the calls are easy—most customers are polite, their questions simple, the answers already highlighted in yellow on my script. But my mind keeps drifting to home, to the promise I made to my stepson last week. He’s been counting down the days until I buy him that Nintendo, his eyes lighting up every time he mentions it. I want to keep that promise, to be the reliable step-parent he deserves, but the commission from these calls barely covers rent, let alone a new game console. My supervisor expects unwavering focus, but my heart aches with the weight of my stepson’s hope. The phone rings again, and I force a cheerful greeting, my voice steady even as my thoughts spiral. I can’t shake the feeling that no matter what I do, I’ll be letting someone down.
